div.head: Hard wax for imprinting seals
div.ab: It is made from white wax, which is harder than the other, & one mixes in very finely ground ceruse or lead white until it becomes as hard as you fancy, adding to it a drop of turpentine to bind it. Next mix in whatever color you want. That is the wax goldsmiths use for modeling.

div.head: Feet of smalls lizards for gold and silver
div.ab: Because the feet of these, which are very small, are very delicate, as you molded the top and d uncovered the belly & the bottom of the feet, cover them lightly with wax & then cast the second mold. And the wax being removed, it leaves a g little gate for the aforesaid feet. And should the bottom of these come of in one piece, you can repair it. And the scales from the top of the toes will come out well.

div.head: Marks from the points of iron wire which are found on the head of the animal
div.ab: LWith the points, one has previously set the shape, especially that of the head. But the head being pierced, there remains around the hole some moisture and a little excretion , which hinders the sand from covering the point & there always remains some little openingg. But to avoid this, you can plant in the slab a iron point, arro cleaned & rounded at the top end & on this end place there a little hard wax or du some mastic or cement, and through the means of this hot iron wire, hold thre the throat of the animal, which can be removed when you come to uncover the belly & the throat to make the second cast.

div.head: Clamps and broken mold
div.ab: When you have made the first reheating & removed the clamps, and you have the opened your mold to clean it by blowing, with quicksilver, which is used only in enclosed molds, close the mold again & put the clamps on again, but not in the first place where they were. Lut again & dry again. But if it is for a cast with silver or gold, lute with the remainder of the sand that was used, for it is the safest. If you mold, while reheating, is broken, you can adjust it with some clamps & lute.
